utterances: Because our financial system is such that when one thing happens with a big institution, it affects many other institutions, because all of these banks lend to each other overnight, many of these banks - the shareholders of these banks get nervous.
So one shareholder of another bank, maybe a larger bank, looks at IndyMac and says, oh my God, I'm worried about this, that bank is in the same business that my company is in.
So they start selling shares, market value plunges.
I mean, you get to a point where so many things are tied together that any one failure could topple conceivably the entire system, if it is big enough.
That didn't happen in this case, but it is significant.
What about federal insurance?
What kind of protection does the federal government offer to the people who are invested in this bank?
Well, to investors in the bank, it doesn't really offer any protection.

If you are a depositor, of course, there is the FDIC insurance, you see that big sticker when you walk into any bank branch, it says your deposits are ensured up to a 100,000 dollars by the Federal Government.
That's the federal - what the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.
does for banks.
But if you are an investor, you are stuck, I mean, if you have shares in a company, that's the risk that you take, this is the downside of investing.
You put your money into a company.
Those shares are worth 20 bucks when you buy them, if they drop to five, you are out.
If they go up to 25 dollars a share, then you made a five dollar a share profit.
But if the company fails, there is no protection for you, at least not from the federal government.
Do you think that a company like this, shares might end up in, say, 401(k)s and people's retirement plans?
It is possible.
I mean, it would all, you would have to really look closely at what you are, what's in your 401(k).

Many people in their 401(k)s have funds, or even funds of funds, you know, there are companies who would put together a portfolio, and many times you'll go and look at your 401(k), and they say, OK, choose this portfolio if you are going to retire in 20 to 30, choose this portfolio if you are going to retire 10 years from now.
And what you really have to do is look at the prospectus for those funds that you have in your 401(k), to be able to figure out what your 401(k)'s holdings are.

If you are in a 401 - my guess is that most 401(k)s tend to be so diversified that one company, one bank's failure is not going to be too heavily weighted in your own personal account that it is going to affect your retirement.
So nobody should worry there.
The bigger problem, again, comes in if this becomes a broader issue for financial stocks, and your 401(k) is holding a good deal of those.
It might be a good time to check, but I don't think an individual holder of a 401(k) retirement account really has anything to worry about from this.
So let's go back to the issue of people who are depositing.
Remind us again how much the limit is for full coverage from the Federal Government.
And then, what happens when you reach that limit?
It is a hundred grand, and after a hundred grand it is a good idea for you to be diversified in where you have your money.
I mean, in most cases you are not going to have somebody with 100,000 dollars cash, or more than 100,000 dollars cash sitting in one particular checking account.
And many banks, most financial institutions are going to have different options for you beyond just those deposits.
But for the federal insurance limit, it is up to 100,000 dollars, and then, after that, the insurance is gone, and you are not necessarily covered.

Which is why one of the reasons why you are told that if you have a large amount of cash, you want to look at diversifying, doing different things with the money, as opposed to keeping it all sitting in one place.
I want to bring in Kai Wright now.

He is a columnist, and recently had a cover article for The Nation titled ""The Subprime Swindle: How Banks Stole Black America's Hard Won Wealth and Gambled it Away in Risky Investment Schemes."" You can also find an article on the website TheRoot, and it's on the front page when I went to look at it today.
You talk about your own mother having to give up her house.
Tell me about that.

Well, I mean, I think one of the significant things there, similar to the folks, the family I profiled, a number of the families that I interviewed down in Atlanta, is there is this, there is a lot of shame.
You know, there is this belief that, you know, you have done something wrong, and now you are in this position.

And so what that means is that folks end up waiting too long, beating their heads against brick walls for too long, before they get around to asking for help from either other family members, or from the variety of sort of nonprofits that are out there trying to help them, or even trying to engage the lender to say, hey listen, this is a bad deal I got, what are we going to do about it before it gets to be too late?
So it is not until it gets to be too late that folks are talking about.
That was the same thing that happened with my mom, that's the same thing that happened with the family I profiled.
They got themselves into these situation, or got drawn into these situations I would argue, and then - and hid it some from everybody in their lives until the last minute.
You profiled an older gentleman who kind of got into a cycle of just - it is like the cartoons of the snowball becoming the avalanche.
Tell me what happened to him.
He is a guy who bought his house in 1968.
It's one of the things we hear about with this is, oh, you know, the sub-primes, they had - they did as much good as bad because they encourage minority home ownership.
We got first-time buyers in, but a very small percentage of the sub-prime loans since '98 actually went to first-time home buyers.
He is an example of what more than half of them were refinances.
He had his house since 1968, and it became a very important part of the family, both for their financial security, but then also just for a wide range of stability.
And they owned it, and borrowed responsibly against it for, you know, for 30-some-odd years, and then 2003, I believe it was, they got a 68,000 dollar refinance for to put up some new siding.
And in the course of four years, they flipped through four more refinances that landed him owing 125,000 dollars on a house that is, at an outside, worth 100,000 dollars.

And through a whole host of questionable practices to get him into that loan, and one of the most strike - he had an IndyMac loan and, you know, they did a lot of these no-documentation loans, that's part of the problem they ran against.
And he had one of these, where, you know, here is a guy who is living on a Postal Service pension and Social Security, and the loan application said he makes 5,000 dollars a month.
Indymac told me they didn't think that was a red flag, but it seems to me anybody interested in actually underwriting these loans would have said wait a minute here.
Keith, is that illegal, overstating income?
Is there a law against it?
There is a new regulation that was just passed today that would have required the bank, Indymac in that case, to have proof of the lender's income before making that loan.
Up until now, that was completely legal, it was unregulated and you could - you could do it.

It is unethical, banks have been sued for doing that and in some cases they've been prosecuted, but you have to do a very careful prosecution because in many cases and in many states this wasn't - these mortgage lenders weren't regulated.
One of the differences between Indymac and banks in general and many of the bigger sub-prime players was that mortgage companies and banks are different.
In other words, if you're a bank and you have that federal insurance in a charter, as a bank you have to follow federal lending regulations.
If you're a mortgage lender and you're not technically a bank, you are immune - you had been immune for, you know, until now, from many of the regulations.
The states didn't regulate them.
The federal government didn't regulate them.
And there was the flip in the percentage of mortgages that were done, it used to be that most of mortgages were done by banks, most mortgage lending was done by banks.
And now, or at least in the last five or seven years, the majority of that lending shifted over to mortgage companies.
And so you had far more lending happening on a level where it was not regulated than you did by a bank or an institution that had federal oversight at all.
As a result you also have far more sub-prime lending related to that, and in particular in African-American and Latino neighborhoods.
And, you know, one of the things - with this regulation conversation, one of the ways it's been framed as though, you know, it was this sort of accidental vacuum.

But it really was a vacuum that was exploited both by these unregulated lenders and the larger banks that own them in some cases, that would have been regulated, but they had these subsidiaries in order to be able to do this kind of lending.
And, you know, we talk about it as the exploding interest rates and that's what we think about sub-prime.
But, you know, it's actually a much broader category of stuff, from these no-doc and low-doc loans to, you know, inflated appraisals.
To just the - really, the way in which the loan is made.

You know, you go into a neighborhood like the one George Mitchell (ph) lived in and they find people like him, and say listen, hey, you've got all this equity you're wasting and convince them, you know, you should borrow this money, you should borrow a larger loan.
Borrow a larger and larger loan.
Of which they get no benefit whatsoever, you know.
I mean, he got 360 dollars out of his last 125,000 dollar loan.

Welcome back, guys.
And I'm going to move straight into another big issue.
We talked a little bit about the banking side of things.
Now Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are the two largest mortgage finance companies in the country.
They have over half of America's mortgages.
Keith, what exactly are these two entities, and what is going on?
They're in trouble right now.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are interesting companies because in that they're private, but they are supported and backed by the U.S.
government.
I don't think many people ever expected them to have to reach out for the kind of backing they're now getting.
But essentially what they do is they will go out and they will back or they will underwrite many of the mortgages that happen.

So that if you're a bank and you go out and someone wants to - or lend and someone wants to borrow money from you, it becomes easier for that bank to lend money because they know that Fannie and Freddie will purchase the mortgage from the bank.
And so if you've got somebody who maybe would have been on the bubble, maybe wouldn't have qualified for the best rate, maybe he wouldn't have been able to borrow the money for the house.
Fannie and Freddie have been something of a safety net to the borrower, if not the mortgage industry itself, for decades.
So what's going on with them?
This is Talk of the Nation, I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Updating today's top story, the House of Representatives defeated the $700-billion-bailout bill earlier today.
Despite intense pressure from the White House and leaders in Congress, the bill fell more than 20 votes short.
All right.
What do I win?
Well, essentially what's happening is they've got a lot of bad mortgages just like every other lender out there right now because - because they buy so many lenders.
And this is one of the - has been one of the fundamental problems with the housing crisis and really the credit crisis.
Many mortgages, as we've talked about before, were not held on to by the banks that bought them which is why so many bad mortgages were written.
If I lent you five bucks and then I sell the debt to Kai, it's Kai's responsibility to come after you for the money.
So I don't have to worry about you ever paying me back the five dollars.
Well Fannie and Freddie are in the business of guaranteeing mortgages so the banks can make many mortgages - can make all these loans that, you know, that they don't have to worry about.
Well, Fannie and Freddie are the ones who at the end of the day are left holding onto the paper - what's called the paper which is, you know, the note that guarantees that mortgage.
With so many people in default and people falling behind and the economy being what it is, they just ran into liquidity problems like many other banks are running into liquidity problems.
And they needed not so much a bailout, but they needed an extension of credit.
Alright, Kai, I want to return to what this means for black America.
When you have these major issues of turbulence and shifts in the financial world, what does it mean for the wealth of black families and inter-generational wealth for example?
Well I mean this is the thing.
There's so many different echo effects from this that are particularly - felt particularly hard in black America.
So it's sort of - at the familial level there's - you know, home equity is such an outsized proportion of what black wealth exists.
There's a huge wealth gap in America in the first instance.

But to the degree that it gets closed is through home equity, and when you remove, I believe the status that once you remove home equity from the wealth equation, blacks own about a percentage of the wealth of their white counterparts.
So it's such a big important part of what wealth status we have.

And, you know, you look at a family again like the Mitchell's, you know, they had the house for a generation and it would have been something that as George went into the end his life was something that his children, his middle-aged children would have inherited, would have been some capital that they could have used.
And instead, they are using their money now to try to support that.
So not only do they not get the inheritance, they get - they have to then take what resources they do have, take their wealth and flow it backwards to try shore up to keep George in his house.
So on the familial level it's really - it really limits that sort of generation-to-generation movement that you see in other communities.
Let me just say very briefly, and I know that you were going to go into some other aspects, but we have to wrap this up.
Keith first, and then Kai.
Do you think that as a whole we could end up with African-Americans, in terms of wealth, being worse off compared to white Americans in say 10 or 15 years?
I don't think that that's a question.
I mean, unless something dramatic were to happen.
You have to look at how far back as a whole African-Americans are compared to the rest of the population, particularly compared to white Americans in terms of wealth.
The gap is enormous.
And unless something drastic happens, I don't expect it to be closed in the next 10 or 15 years.

Now there could be some momentum made, but to the extent that that momentum begins to shift is going to depend on when the financial markets, when the housing markets, when employment, when all of the things that enable a person or a community to gain wealth, begin to turn around.
And I don't see that happening honestly in the next anywhere near before the next 12 or maybe even 18 months.
Yeah.
Kai, do you think that there should be some kind of collective action from African-American groups, and who might those be or is everybody on their own?
Well I mean you know, without it - the bottom line is without a large-scale public investment we are going to see a widening of the gap.
I mean for one, there'll be a net loss in black home ownership between the beginning of sub-prime and now.
So we will have lost ground in home ownership.

Two, with the disproportionate impact of these foreclosures on black neighborhoods, you have all of these empty properties sitting in black neighborhoods returning these areas that were up and coming in many cases, that we had spent years investing in to try to undo the losses of the 80's, that's all going to be reversed without some sort of massive public investment to do something with those properties and to get people out of these bad loans.
